summary: This document is a series of email exchanges between prosecutors and defense attorneys regarding discovery production in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It discusses technical issues with file transfers, redactions in flight records, and logistics for delivering hard drives to Maxwell at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC).

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell, corresponding with prosecutors about discovery issues, redactions, and drive logistics.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Defense attorney cc'd on discovery correspondence regarding production issues and redactions.

persons.name: Thomas J. Powers
persons.context: Dropped off hard drives for discovery and is involved in the logistical coordination of discovery materials.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney cc'd on discovery correspondence regarding production and redactions.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Defense attorney cc'd on discovery correspondence regarding production and redactions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the case, referenced as receiving discovery materials at the MDC.

connections.description: Everdell is communicating with prosecutors to ensure Maxwell receives discovery materials at MDC.
Cohen is part of the defense team working on discovery issues for Maxwell.
Both are part of the defense team coordinating discovery logistics, with Powers handling physical drive drop-off.
Both are defense attorneys cc'd on the same discovery correspondence.

events.title: Discovery Production Deadline
events.description: Deadline for the government to complete production of initial non-electronic discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Hard Drive Drop-off
events.description: Thomas J. Powers dropped off two hard drives for discovery at the defense firm.

locations: Southern District of New York, New York, NY 10007
Cohen & Gresser LLP, New York, NY 10022
keyFacts: Prosecutors redacted flight records from airlines (American, Delta, Southwest, United) for flights within the past decade, claiming they post-date offense conduct and are not subject to disclosure under Rule 16.
Defense attorneys raised concerns about redactions in discovery documents, arguing they were unnecessary given the protective order.
Technical issues with file transfers and McAfee encryption software caused problems with discovery production, requiring replacement documents.
Logistical coordination was underway to deliver a hard drive with all discovery to date to Ghislaine Maxwell at the MDC by August 21, 2020.
The defense team included attorneys Christian Everdell, Mark S. Cohen, Jeff Pagliuca, Laura Menninger, and Thomas J. Powers.
